_meta.instructions: Merge rules: (A) fixes: apply UNCONDITIONALLY. (B) updates: overwrite only null/empty fields. (C) removals: delete exercises by id. (D) new_exercises: append.
_meta.notes_on_lattice_lactate_removal: lattice_lactate_8x8 was flagged for removal in BRIEF B (volume anomalous: 64 problems/session unrealistic, protocol unverified). This patch includes its removal. Net count change: -1 (remove) + 1 (add thirty_thirty) = 0.

removals._reason: Protocol 8x8 = 64 boulder problems per session. No verified Lattice source found for this specific volume. Notes say 'grade ~flash level' but 64 problems at flash is physiologically implausible. Flagged in BRIEF B and confirmed here. Remove and reintroduce only with verified source.

fixes._comment: BUG: work_seconds and rest both null — engine cannot prescribe. EMOM is self-timed (start every 60s) but work_seconds=30 provides an anchor for UI display. rest is implicit (remainder of 60s), kept null with improved note.

prescription_defaults.notes: Every Minute On the Minute: start a problem at 0:00, 1:00, 2:00... rest is whatever remains of each minute. Typical problem takes 20-30s. Grade 2-4 below boulder max. 12 problems = 12 min. Reduce grade mid-session to maintain form — EMOM trains capacity, not failure.

fixes._comment: BUG: work_seconds and rest both null. Bechtel OTM: 10 problems over 10 min, then 10 min rest, 2 sets total. Fixed to match Bechtel spec (climbing.com). 2-min cycle per problem: work ~45s, rest ~75s = implicit in the 120s cycle.

prescription_defaults.notes: One problem every 2 minutes: start at 0:00, 2:00, 4:00... 10 problems = 20 min per set. 10 min rest between sets. Grade at or just above flash: harder than EMOM since longer rest allows harder effort. Stop if form breaks. Bechtel OTM protocol.

updates.description: Campus board arm sprints for alactic-aerobic capacity. Up-and-down the largest rungs as fast as possible for 15-20 seconds. Trains the alactic PCr system to rapidly reload between explosive efforts — the mechanism that allows hard boulderers to do multiple attempts with short rest. High injury risk: warm up thoroughly, stop if shoulder fatigue appears. (Hörst PE protocols; campus endurance progressions)
cues: Largest rungs only: this is not a strength exercise, it is a sprint
Go as fast as possible — each 15s effort is near-max arm speed
If you can't reach the top rung, skip fewer rungs on the next set
Stop immediately at any shoulder elevation or shrugging — campus work demands scapular engagement throughout
120s rest between sets: full PCr recovery before the next all-out sprint

updates.description: Every Minute On the Minute bouldering: one problem per minute for 10-12 rounds. The fixed 60-second clock progressively reduces rest as sessions advance — early rounds feel easy, later rounds increasingly pump. Trains aerobic power and recovery ability at submaximal climbing intensity. Ideal format for building density of hard moves without exceeding anaerobic threshold. (Hörst EMOM; Lattice aerobic power intervals)
cues: Start each problem exactly at the minute mark — use a visible timer
Grade: 2-4 below boulder max. Problems should be high-percentage to avoid failure mid-round
Rest is whatever remains of each 60s — if you're using under 30s per climb, go harder
When round 8-12 starts to feel hard, that's the training stimulus — don't reduce grade unless you'll fail
Progress: 12 rounds → 15 rounds → 1 level harder at 12 rounds

updates.description: On The Minute bouldering (Bechtel): 10 problems over 20 minutes, one every 2 minutes, then 10-minute rest. The 2-minute cycle allows harder problems than EMOM while still accumulating training density over the session. Tracks improvement by noting total problems completed per session over the training cycle. Use on a home wall or spray wall where you know the problems well. (Bechtel climbing.com; OTM progression model)
cues: 2-minute cycle: problem starts at 0:00, 2:00, 4:00... rest is whatever remains between problems
Grade: just above or at flash level — harder than EMOM because you have more rest
Know your problems in advance — onsighting during OTM wastes time and breaks flow
If problems are taking >35 seconds, they are too hard: switch to lower grade
Progress: add 1 problem per session, not 1 grade. Volume before intensity.

updates.description: Link 3-5 boulder problems back-to-back without rest between them. Each circuit of 3-5 linked problems constitutes one set. Grade is 2-3 below boulder flash so each individual problem is manageable but accumulated pump over the circuit creates anaerobic lactic stress. Closest to route climbing specificity among all bouldering PE protocols. (Hörst PE protocols; Lattice Boulder Triples pattern)
cues: Choose 3-5 problems you can reliably flash individually — linking is the challenge, not each problem
No rest between problems in a circuit: step off one and onto the next immediately
Grade target: 2-3 below individual flash. By problem 4-5 you should feel significant pump
5 min rest between circuits: this is a minimum. Take more if needed to restore quality
Sets 2-3 will feel much harder than set 1 — that metabolic accumulation is the point

new_exercises.name: 30/30 Climbing Intervals

prescription_defaults.notes: 6 intervals of 30s all-out / 30s rest = 1 set. 10 min rest between sets. 2-4 sets total (well-conditioned climbers only). RPE 9-10/10 during work. Climb intuitive open-hold style — no set problems. Use smallest holds possible without falling. As you fatigue, move to bigger holds rather than stopping.

new_exercises.description: Hörst 30/30 intervals: 30 seconds all-out climbing alternating with 30 seconds rest, 6 intervals = 1 round. Patented by Eric Hörst as the elite PE protocol that exhausts alactic power while building aerobic power (to drive PCr recovery) without excessive lactic accumulation. Done on spray walls or system boards — no set problems, climb intuitively at max intensity. Contraindicated early in training cycles; program 2-4 weeks max before performance phase. (Hörst trainingforclimbing.com; Cameron Horst climbing.com)
cues: 30s work: absolute maximum intensity — the smallest holds you can hold without falling
30s rest: shake out below heart level, chalk up, breathe deeply. Time this exactly
6 intervals per round: difficulty escalates. Early rounds easy, rounds 5-6 extremely hard
10 min rest between rounds: PCr system needs full recovery to deliver max quality
Stop if a round is clearly failing before 30s — quality over quantity in every session
